citeinfo.title: Behavior of Pacific Walruses Tracked from the Alaska Coast of the Chukchi Sea

descript.abstract: We tracked movments and haulout foraging behavior of walruses instrumented with satellite-linked data loggers from the Alaskan shores of the Chukchi Sea during the autumn of 2009 (n=13) and 2010 (n=2).
descript.purpose: The Pacific walrus (Odobenus rosmarus divergens) is a large Arctic pinniped of the Chukchi and Bering Seas. Large losses of sea ice are projected to occur in the Arctic by mid-century, which raises concerns for the conservation of the Pacific walrus. In recent years disappearance of summer sea ice over the Chukchi Sea continental shelf has prompted walruses foraging in the Chukchi Sea to seek rest on the coast. Resting on the coast presents many novel stresses to adult female and juvenile walruses, including increased mortality due to trammeling events, possible increased disease transmission and restrictions on foraging range. To understand the significance of resting on the coasts to walruses, it would be useful to understand the walrus resting and foraging time budgets and to understand the extent of movements from the coasts. For this purpose we tracked the behavior of walruses that rested on the US shores of the Chukchi Sea during when sea ice was absent. We collected daily tracking data along with hourly resting and foraging status from walruses that we instrumented as they rested on the Alaskan Chukchi Sea coast.

(2005)|Comments: Trichecidae Gray (1821) and Rosmaridae Gill (1866) are invalid (International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, 1959). The enigmatic walruses have been placed as: (1) the sister group to the otariids (Árnason, 1977; Árnason et al., 1995; Couturier and Dutrillaux, 1986; Dragoo and Honeycutt, 1997; Repenning and Tedford, 1977; Sarich, 1969a, b; Vrana et al., 1994); (2) in the family Otariidae (Barnes, 1989; Mitchell, 1975b); (3) the sister group to the phocids (Berta, 1994; Berta and Wys...|2007-08-15 10:57:25| [CM]|18036|Wilson & Reeder, eds. (2005)|Comments: Although the names in Brisson (1762) are invalid, Odobenus has been retained (International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, 1955a, 1957e, 1998). Placed in Subfamily Odobeninae, Family Phocidae by McKenna and Bell (1997). Placed in separate family by Rice (1998)|2007-08-15 10:57:25| [CM]|18220|David Nicolson - ITIS Data Development Coordinator|Wilson & Reeder (eds., 1993) note that "the pinnipeds (otariids, odobenids, and phocids) are included within the suborder Caniformia; placing them in a separate Order would make the Carnivora paraphyletic." This arrangement continues to be followed in Wilson & Reeder (eds., 2005)|2007-08-15 10:57:25| [CM]|18551|Wilson & Reeder, eds.
